Fields.DialogueText: There you are, Nenohi! I'd been meaning to come find you, but the war has been... well, let's say "progressing apace" and leave it at that.
Ah, Kanchou, oaidekiteureshīdesu! Will you take tea with me?
Not right this moment - I need to talk with you about the disposition of the fleet.
All the more reason to take tea! It will calm our spirits before we plunge headlong into battle once again.
Well, I suppose I can't argue with that. Tell me, Nenohi, how do you feel you can best serve the fleet?
On the battle line, of course! Am I not a fearsome warship, the Emperor's own sword, raised to defend his people?
I suppose I'll have to take your word for it on that one.

Fields.MenuText: In the meantime, what are practical things you could do to serve the fleet?
Are you sure you're comfortable with work at the front? We have other ships that could carry the load.
Did you see much combat before you came under my command? Having a veteran ship is always a plus.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose hunting for underwater threats and aircraft, as befits my role as a destroyer. I know others are better armed, but I have enthusiasm!
Quite comfortable! None will find my spirit lagging in this fight!
Yes, Kanchou, I was fighting the Chinese well before the war broke out. It seems Japan never lacks for an enemy.
*ALARM*
That's the alarm - we'll talk about this later. Still, good to see you!
@BATTLE
Hey, Nenohi, I hope I didn't catch you at a bad time. I don't mean to interrupt.
Daijōbuda yo! I am simply enjoying a chat with a few of the crew. Run along now, boys!
Stay out of trouble, gentlemen.
You get along very well with them.
Of course I do, Kanchou! My sisters may be content fighting for glory, but it is important to me to know the men who crew me.
It is only recently that I can speak to them myself, but they have always spoken to me.
That's a somewhat surprising position for a warship, but I can tell the sailors appreciate it.
Indeed. And they know I will help fulfill their wishes should the worst happen to them out here.

Fields.MenuText: That's very good of you. The specter of death is never far away out here.
I'm sure it's a great comfort to them to know that the ship they crew cares that much about them.
Have you had to perform those services often?

Fields.DialogueText: No, no it is not. Though, like a wart on an elderly relative, it is best not to call attention to it.
Hah, that may be the greatest comfort of all. It is why we are born with names, I assume, so that men may ask us for help.
I would rather not speak of this too much, Kanchou. Know that it is more than a few.
*ALARM*
Arāmu! We must take places.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I need to talk to you about the tactics you're using out there. I'm not sure you're being used to the best of your ability.
Dōiu imidesu ka? Have I caused an issue amongst the fleet?
No, no, nothing like that. It's just that you seem to be a bit too eager to get to grips with the enemy.
Isn't that what we're here for, Kanchou? We are slaying monsters so that the world is a safer place.
True. I'm just saying that you really shouldn't be trying to get ahead of the rest of the fleet like that.
We have cruisers and battleships for a reason - your job is more that of an escort.
That's just nonsense, Kanchou. I have guns, I can fight, and there are enemies ahead. I owe it to the fleet to fight them.

Fields.MenuText: You owe it to the fleet to stay in position so we don't get defeated in detail.
If you go out there ahead of everyone, we won't be able to help you if you start getting overwhelmed.
Are you sure you should be taking that kind of speed? By yourself out in front, you might need to maneuver faster than you can.

Fields.DialogueText: You raise a good point. But, on the other hand, I want to kill monsters and I am very good at it.
Who's to say I'll find myself in such a situation?
Are you saying I can't handle myself, Kanchou? Because I find that insulting both to myself and to my brave crew.
*ALARM*
Arāmu! Tell the rest of the fleet to catch me if they can, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
I had some questions to ask you, Nenohi. Most of the warships under my command did not see much action before the war.
Given your experience in the Chinese theater, I thought you might be able to help give some advice to the others.
Well, I appreciate you saying so, Kanchou, but I'm not sure what I can do for them.
Don't be modest, Nenohi. You may be brash, but no one can doubt your experience or effectiveness.
Oh no, Kanchou, I mean I'm most comfortable with Japanese terminology and military theory. I'm not sure I can speak to the rest of the crews and ships.

Fields.MenuText: In that case, I'll get some translators together to make sure your advice gets through.
You can start with the Japanese ships then, and we'll work on the others afterwards.
Just tell me what you've been telling new recruits to your crew, and I'll pass the information along.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, so much attention! That sounds fabulous, and I would love to be a part of it.
Well, I do think a few of my sisters could use a hand. They're so focused on battle.
Hah, if you have time, Kanchou, I would love to. I have so many stories to tell.
*ALARM*
I suppose we'll have to wait though, that's the alarm.
I could start with how to respond to alarms, hah! Battlestations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Kanchou! I am very much enjoying my teaching duties. Watashi no koto o kangaete kurete arigatō.
You're very welcome. From what I hear, your students are learning quite a bit.
Thank you for saying so. I always enjoy being able to help my comrades in arms.
Well I'm glad I gave you the opportunity! Hopefully your knowledge will continue to spread throughout the fleet.
We've been really hurting for a fleet-wide standard protocol for dealing with the Morganas. Every country has different naval strategies.
Well, I would love to help with that too, even if I can only speak for the Japanese Navy.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps I should get you to talk to the other ships and see if we can all get together to discuss strategy.
Having a representative from the Japanese Navy would be vital.
I'm glad to hear your enthusiasm. I'll have to see about making this happen as soon as possible.

Fields.DialogueText: You mean a large strategy meeting, instead of all the little ones? That would be tricky to put together.
Well, we do have one of the largest navies, for better or worse.
Please do, Kanchou! I do love the chance to do good and to work together with my allies!
*ALARM*
There's the alarm! I'll give this more thought after the battle.
I'm looking forward to hearing your plan.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, you came! Yōkoso! Please, look around, tell me what you think.
It's very pretty, Nenohi - but why did you string ribbons everywhere? Is it a holiday I am unaware of?
Gomen'nasai - I didn't mean to confuse you! I just wanted to liven things up for the crew a little bit! Isn't it nice?
Yes, it's nice. And I'm sure the crew really appreciates your thinking of them like this.
Well, they certainly do seem to be stepping lively. I just think it is important that the men do not spend their lives staring at shades of grey and blue.
There is so much more to our lives than this war, and it is important to me that we do not forget this.

Fields.MenuText: A laudable sentiment, Nenohi. I wish we had more time in this war to stop and smell the roses.
I am glad you are here to remind us, Nenohi. It would be worrisome if we lost sight of what we're fighting for.
I'm not sure we have time for such frivolities, and I also don't think we can afford to waste the materials.

Fields.DialogueText: One must strive to make time, Kanchou. If we do not, how will we remember what we fight for?
Yet another way I can serve my brothers and sisters in the fleet. I aim to please, of course.
I don't think we can afford not to, Kanchou. The men will grow despondent without it.
I can't argue with that. Maybe I need to get your advice on this as well.
*ALARM*
We'll have to shelf that conversation for a later date, Kanchou. That's the alarm.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, there you are! What are you doing in the engine room? There's a strategy meeting starting soon.
Oh, I know, Kanchou - I hadn't forgotten. I was just trying to decide the best way to liven things up in here.
It's an engine room, Nenohi. It isn't exactly known for being bright and cheerful.
Nazena no? Why couldn't it be a comfortable place for the crew when they're hard at work? There's no reason it should be a place of gloom.
Well, you certainly have me there. Still, no ribbons... or anything else that might burst into flames.
Hai! I've sort of ruled out anything that could catch fire, not to worry.
Do you have any suggestions, Kanchou? I'm always open to new and interesting ideas.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I think a mural would be nice. Remind the crew what they're fighting for out here.
Maybe some more light that doesn't come from the engines themselves. It looks a bit grim right now.
Why not let the crew choose, ask them what appeals to them and then work from there?

Fields.DialogueText: That's not a bad plan. Many of these men have been away from home for some time, after all.
Oooh, not a bad idea. I could get some mirrors or vents and set some natural light in here as well.
If I left it up to the crew, I have no doubt less... mature voices would win out. If I'm going to go to the effort, I want to make sure it's in good taste.
*ALARM*
We'll have to talk about it later. It sounds like the enemy has found us.
@BATTLE
Nenohi! I've been thinking about what you said earlier, about your comfort levels with non-Japanese military terminology.
It's one of my less interesting attributes, Kanchou. What brought it to mind?
I was perusing the translations of your tactical advice and war stories, and it started me thinking about how useful that could be.
The translators did a fine job, but nothing beats a story straight from the source. How would you feel about a language tutor?
Sugoi! Oh, that would be excellent, Kanchou! I've learned so much from the crew, but so much of what I say in other languages just feels... imprecise.
Have you arranged for this already?
Of course I have - I wouldn't be here without an answer to this question.

Fields.MenuText: I thought we'd start with an English tutor. You've probably seen plenty of English writing, thanks to American visits to Japan.
If it's not too rough, I thought we'd start with Russian. The Soviets are so close to Japan, after all.
We have a number of folks from the Pacific Islands in the crews, I thought you might start with one of their languages.

Fields.DialogueText: An excellent idea, Kanchou! I remember the stories of Admiral Perry arriving on our shores, bringing wonders with him.
This is true. I'm sure it won't be easy... but I'll do my best to learn.
I'm not sure how happy they will be to listen to a Japanese Belle, Kanchou. My government doesn't always treat its neighbors well.
All right, we'll figure out the logistics soon. Intel suggested a Morgana fleet nearby.
*ALARM*
That alarm means someone was right. I shall see you on the line, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I needed your opinion on... What exactly do you have there?
Oh, these are my stamps, Kanchou! Are they not so beautiful and varied?
They certainly are that. I had no idea you were a stamp collector. How did someone like you even get into the hobby?
Well, I do travel, don't I, Kanchou? And I make a point of picking up at least one or two new stamps from every port I visit.
They are always so colorful, and interesting, and they tell you so much about the culture that birthed them.
That's a remarkably inclusive view for a warship, Nenohi. I'm impressed.
There is more to me than my armament, you know.

Fields.MenuText: All right, then - what's your favorite stamp so far?
I apologize. How many stamps do you have, anyway?
You certainly are, Nenohi. Tell me, what stamp do you wish you have, but don't?

Fields.DialogueText: I have a rare stamp of the cherry trees in bloom around the road to Mt. Fuji. There are not many of them, and it is quite old.
Oh, Kanchou, how can you ask such a question? I have more stamps than I know what to do with, and not nearly enough.
I have heard great things of the Canadian stamps, adorned with beautiful mountains and trees I have never seen.
*ALARM*
We'll have to put a pin in that talk for now, that sounds like the alarm.
No pins in my stamps!
@BATTLE
How are things going with the translator, Nenohi? Picking the language up as quickly as you had hoped?
Sōde wa nai to omoimasu. It's just... so hard sometimes to find words that mean exactly what I want to say. And so many sounds are different!
Hah, well, that'll happen when you're learning an entirely different language. You're lucky you found a tutor when you're this young.
Assuming it matters for Belles.
Is it harder to learn new languages when you're older? I didn't know that.
Well, it typically is for the rest of us. It hadn't actually occurred to me to wonder if it's the same way for you.
I suppose we'll find out - won't we, Kanchou? Nothing will stop me from seeing to this task!

Fields.MenuText: Well, I certainly can't fault your enthusiasm in this endeavour. Or anything really.
If it doesn't work, it doesn't work. You're still a solid member of the fleet.
As long as it keeps you busy, you can take as long as you need to get it done.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, enthusiasm is one of my finest traits, Kanchou! I am nothing if not driven!
Yes, but there is always the opportunity to do more, is there not, Kanchou? No one can say you are an idle hand.
Spoken like someone who secretly did not enjoy the new wall hangings in their cabin. For shame Captain.
*ALARM*
I suppose it'll have to wait, though.
Yoroshiku! And I was just learning the proper verbs to war with!
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I wanted to ask a favor of you. I've noticed that your Japanese crewmen get along much better with the rest of the crew than other Japanese crews I've seen.
With that in mind, I was hoping your crewmen could speak to some of the others, and encourage them to better work with those of other nationalities.
Ahhh. I can try, Kanchou, but I think it has less to do with the crewmen themselves, and more to do with my effect on my crew.
My nation has historically been distrustful of foreigners, but I myself am not. In fact, such behavior has always bothered me.
I prefer to take the world one day at a time, and to see what beauty life has to offer. And I think my crew is affected by my outlook.

Fields.MenuText: I had no idea a Belle could be so at odds with her own government.
I think your philosophy will serve you better in the long run. This war won't last forever, after all.
I'm glad to have you with us, Nenohi. You're an inspiration to the rest of us in receiving what life has to offer.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, we are free thinkers, some of us. I know you're a Kanchou, but I assume you ask questions sometimes as well.
I only hope you are right, Kanchou. It has lasted too long already.
Hah, you make me sound like a hedonist, Kanchou. I simply wish to make the most of our time here.
We might have to save the philosophizing for later. We should be sighting the enemy any moment.
Let me at them, Kanchou. I will show them what we can do.
@BATTLE
You really need to stop running ahead of the fleet like that, Nenohi. We've talked about this.
Gomen'nasai... but I engaged them early enough that they were forced to adapt to us, rather than we adapt ourselves to them.
Be that as it may, I am getting a little tired of having to charge the rest of the fleet in after you.
It works, though! Sō janai? When we have the momentum, it is easy to keep them on the back foot.
Yes, but it's also easy for them to defeat us in detail. And we're lucky that hasn't happened yet.
It doesn't help that you still have a habit of only communicating with the fleet in Japanese under fire.
Ahhh. Sore wa hontōda. I do need to be more considerate of the rest of the fleet.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you double down on the language lessons? If you can coordinate with the rest of the fleet, then leading from the front might be an asset.
Darn right you need to. Stay with the rest of the ships unless we make a plan that says otherwise, okay?
Yes, now start obeying orders, or I'll take you off the line.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... that's not a bad plan. And I do so like being out in front where I can protect the others.
All right Kanchou, I will work close to protect the fleet. For now, at least.
Kanchou! I did not know you felt so strongly. I shall do my best.
It looks like we have another fight on our hands. Stay close!
@BATTLE
How are the language lessons going, Nenohi? Progressing smoothly?
It is an interesting conundrum, Kanchou. The words themselves I am learning quickly enough, but nuance eludes me.
There are so many shades of meaning in so many languages. And so many rules that make no sense.
And don't get me started on lewdness. You'd think every language existed to make obliquely naughty references.
I've spent enough time around sailors to think you might be onto something with that last one.
Still, it's good to hear you are learning the languages. They say they get easier with each new one you learn.
Well, then - I should be able to snap them up like nothing after this, shouldn't I, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely. And your experience supplementing your "automatic language" skills could help other Belles too, in the long run.
I should hope so. You've wasted enough time trying to master one, I'd hate to think how long it will take you to learn them all.
As long as you put the ones you do learn to the service of the fleet, I can't fault the speed with which you learn them.

Fields.DialogueText: You think so, Kanchou? Maybe I'm just the only one who needs the help.
Trial and error is an important part of learning anything, Kanchou. Don't pretend otherwise.
Yes yes, I shall serve the fleet. That seems to be all you care about.
*ALARM*
That's the alarm. Quit pouting, we have Morganas to sink.
@BATTLE
Well, Nenohi, I must say I like what you've done with the place. Other than the noise, the engine room is now a very relaxing place.
Not too relaxing, of course. I don't want my crew nodding off while they're working in here.
I would hate to have to explain a Fūsui-related accident to the medical staff.
Fair enough - that was a bit of a stretch. Still, it's a nice thing to do for the engineers and anyone else who wanders down here.
I certainly thought so. I think I'll do the armory next. There are so many implements of death, they could use some lightening up.
I have to say, lightening up a massive room full of guns and ammo is a massive task.
Hai! But nothing worth doing is easy. I'm sure I can make it work properly with some effort.

Fields.MenuText: You have some very strange priorities, Nenohi. Still, I can't argue with the results.
I'm sure, if we try hard enough, we can find something for you to do that isn't just decoration.
I suppose you're right there. If it were easy and worth doing, it would already be done.

Fields.DialogueText: I think my priorities are both in order and very much in line with my skills, Kanchou. I do not very much appreciate being second guessed.
I like decorating, Kanchou! Are you saying my skills are not providing assistance for the fleet?
Things that are easy and worth doing are very few and far between, Kanchou. I'd like to see an example, if you have one.
*ALARM*
Oh, look, the alarm. What a coincidence that that would happen. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
I think the language lessons are going well, Kanchou! I can finally write poetry in another language!
Are you sure that should be your first priority? Those battle orders we talked about might be best to focus on.
There is no beauty in your soul, Kanchou. Poetry is a great test of fluency.
Obeying the rules of a language, the rules of the form, and writing something that makes sense is a great challenge.
That makes sense to me. I'm glad to hear you're excelling at it, then.
I would not say excelling, exactly, Kanchou. I am still making many mistakes, but it is a learning process.

Fields.MenuText: Most things are, when you get right down to it. I'm glad to hear you're persevering.
A war isn't always the best place to be learning new skills, especially ones that might get people killed.
Still, the sooner you're able to communicate, the sooner we'll be able to more effectively strategize with other ships.

Fields.DialogueText: I always do, Kanchou. A few failures, or a few dozen, won't stop me from achieving my goals.
Hah, I know so many who have been forced to learn for this war. Perhaps you simply need to trust me, Kanchou.
Of course, Kanchou. Not that I require additional pressure to do so from you, but I will work harder.
I'm excited to see how well you do once you're telling your stories in person, rather than through an interpreter.
*ALARM*
Yatta! I'm excited to see if I need a translator to make these monsters understand my fury.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I need to talk to you. I'm getting word of strange radio chatter from your bridge.
Ah, Kanchou, I am simply wishing each of our comrades in arms a good morning and a wonderful day!
I am so enjoying learning their languages, and I thought it would be nice for them to hear a friendly voice!
I can see your point, but.. you don't seem to have mastered all the nuances quite yet.
One of the English Belles is a little upset you told her Sindhi-speaking crew members they would be grieving soon, and some of the Swahili speakers are... very confused.
Gomen'nasai! Gomen'nasai! I shall send out apologies to all of my fellows in the fleet immediately!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should just focus on your lessons and let me smooth things over for you.
Yes, I think that would be an excellent way to resolve this issue.
You do what you think is best. Learning a new language is quite a journey.

Fields.DialogueText: If you insist, Kanchou. I do prefer to take ownership of my mistakes, however.
Thank you, Kanchou! I have been practicing apologies for just such an occasion.
It is! And I am stumbling many times, but I am excited by my progress nonetheless.
It is good to see you making progress, so I'll let you get back to your lessons.
*ALARM*
Later, Kanchou, I hear the alarm!
@BATTLE
*gasp*
Woah, Nenohi! Do you always slew that far to the sides on a turn? I never noticed before!
Oh, Kanchou, it's not so bad as all that. I am just a little top heavy, is all.
A toolbox just flew past my head. We aren't even in combat yet! How have you avoided capsizing?
Well, after my sister fell over...
Wait, you lost a sister to maneuvers like these, and you're still out here speeding around like a maniac?
Oh no, Kanchou, I misspoke. She was more like... a cousin. But the government actually learned a lesson there, and rebuilt myself and my sisters.
Now, we are no longer in nearly as much danger of capsizing!

Fields.MenuText: Not nearly as much is still not good. I want you to suspend these high speed maneuvers.
Well, I trust that you know what you're doing. You've been yourself longer than anyone else, after all.
This does not make me feel better about your haring off ahead of the fleet at top speed.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't very well promise to go slow in a warzone, can I Kanchou? It will be fine, trust me.
Haha, very well put, Kanchou! I promise I know my limits and will do nothing I cannot handle.
What would? Continuing to be untouchable on the sea of conflict? You worry too much, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. Take it easy out there, all right?
Your sense of humor continues to delight, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
*sigh*
I'm not going to ask where you came across the giant ribbons, Nenohi.
That is most wise, Kanchou.
I'm not going to ask where you found the time to repaint the entire conning tower.
It certainly wasn't easy, Kanchou.
I'm not even going to ask where you found a cherry tree to plant on the deck.
I have many friends, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: I just want to know if you did any of this for reasons other than wanting to look pretty.
I just want to be assured I'm not going to have anyone coming around and asking questions about fleet resources.
I just want you to promise me the quartermaster isn't having a breakdown right now.

Fields.DialogueText: I do everything for a reason, Kanchou! For practice, for morale, for feng shui, it always has a purpose.
Oh Kanchou, you really should ignore those government dogs who have no understanding of what our lives are like out here.
Of course not, Kanchou! He loves cherry trees... and the cake I baked him.
Sō? Dōomoimasuka? Does it speak to the inner peace of your soul?
Not exactly. I see smoke on the horizon. And I bet the Morganas aren't the artistic type.
@BATTLE
Hello, Nenohi! Some of the other Belles asked me to say hello in person the next time I came to visit.
You are a messenger now, Kanchou? I thought that was what radios were for.
Jōdandesu! I tease, I tease! Tell them I say thank you, and that I very much appreciate their consideration.
It so interesting speaking over the radio to the foreign Belles who speak Japanese... their accents are fascinating!
I'm sure they find your own accent in their native languages just as fascinating.
I think all of this conversation really has gone far in bettering the relationships between Belles in the fleet.

Fields.MenuText: I might have to make you my ambassador if this keeps up. If you learn every language, you can talk to anyone.
Just don't go painting them without asking, okay? Some of them take their markings pretty seriously.
I'm glad to hear it. Good morale is an important part of any fighting force.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh no, Kanchou, I'm still years away from any such proficiency.
Oh, I would never paint another Belle without asking. Unless I had a very lovely paint scheme in mind I was sure they would appreciate...
So serious, Kanchou. You remind me of the admirals back home. They think of nothing but war.
We'll have to have this conversation later, we're coming up on elements of the Morgana fleet.
As you say, Kanchou. I will talk to my friends soon.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, what did I say? Get back to the skirmish line!
Catch me if you can, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
See Kanchou, you worry too much! Daijōbudesu.
Just get back to the line before something terrible happens.
*BOOM*
Kanchou, we've struck a mine! I didn't see it, it wasn't there when the battle started!
They must have dropped it after the fight started.

Fields.MenuText: Get any leaks cut off and try to stay above water. You're top heavy enough as it is.
I told you something like this would happen. You've endangered your whole crew with your recklessness.
I'll send the support vessels. Thank goodness you didn't hit that during the fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Now is not the time for snide remarks, Kanchou! I'll lock it down as fast as I can!
Your I-told-you-so will not keep me above water, Kanchou. The damage looks pretty bad from here.
Arigatō. Hopefully we can keep the hull together long enough. Thank goodness it's reinforced.
The fleet will be on you in a few minutes. Don't worry, we'll have you.
It is nice to have friends to help me in times like these, Kanchou!
We're moving to engage. Are you going to keep pace with the fleet this time?
Hai.
@BATTLE
There. See, that wasn't so bad, was it? Moving with the fleet.
No, Kanchou.
Yeah. Okay. You could not be more obviously displeased. I hope you aren't upset with me for making you sail like you're a part of the fleet.
It's pretty clear the Morganas were able to trick you because you do the same thing every time.
Shitte iru. I know, Kanchou. I am not mad at you. I am mad at myself.

Fields.MenuText: As long as that doesn't stop you from fighting, you can be as mad as you like.
I don't care that much. Just keep doing your job properly and not risking yourself.
Well, no one else is mad at you, so you shouldn't be. Just keep helping the fleet as best you can.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha, Kanchou, you know how to make me laugh. All right, I will do my best.
Hai.
I will always do my best, Kanchou. That is what is upsetting me.
Well, think about that while you go get those seams looked at. I want to make sure your repairs are holding.
Nenohi, you have to get out of this funk. The other Belles say you barely speak to them.
Oh, but Kanchou, I am so angry! I was just like the old men in my government, throwing myself into battle with no thought to those under me.
Sailors died from that mine blast. And my recklessness caused it.
Ah.
They were my responsibility, and I failed them, and now they are dead. If I had been wiser - or more level-headed - they might not be.
There are casualties in any war, Nenohi. We have to honor their sacrifices and keep fighting.
I know, Kanchou, and I will not stop until the world is safe from the monsters from the sea.

Fields.MenuText: That's what I like to hear. We'll make the Morganas pay for your dead sailors.
Good. Soldier on. We will not forget their sacrifices.
None of us will, Nenohi. That's what binds the fleet together. I'm sorry for your loss.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou, that... that's not quite the attitude I was going for.
Understood, Kanchou.
Thank you, Kanchou. It is good that I am here, with my sisters and brothers in arms.
*ALARM*
I can hear the alarm. Do you need a moment?
Thank you, Kanchou... but there is too much work to be done.
@BATTLE
All right, boys and girls, let's do this one by the numbers.
Hai!
@BATTLE
My friend! Hard to port, there are mines ahead! Lovely one, torpedo boat off your starboard, evade!
Nenohi! What are you doing?
Kanchou, we have them on the ropes, but they rally! But I will keep the rest of the fleet safe!
*BOOM*
Where are you getting this information? You're calling to every ship in the fleet!
Every ship is calling me! You put me in the center, so I hear all the radios! But not everyone speaks the same language!

Fields.MenuText: Good grief. Nenohi, I think I have a job for you when this is over.
Good thinking, keep it up. Can you relay my orders as well?
Make sure you keep it professional and don't cut off a priority message, but you keep doing what you're doing.

Fields.DialogueText: When this is over, Kanchou? I have a job for right now!
I can do anything you want, Kanchou! I think I am very much getting the hang of this!
Understood, Kanchou - now I really must get back to it.
I'll find you after. We almost have them now!
@BATTLE
How are you feeling, Nenohi? Nervous at all? We should be meeting the enemy in an hour or so.
A little nervous, Kanchou, but mostly very proud. This is a lot of responsibility, but now I will be able to keep everyone safe.
No one's truly safe in a war - but it's good to know you'll be the hand on the dial, so to speak.
Hah, even better to have a radio operator who does not need to touch the receiver, isn't it?
That's not quite as important as having a radio operator who speaks every language in the fleet, but it is a positive factor.
Well, I do aim to please, Kanchou. My knowledge of language is still very incomplete, but I'm understanding the gist of what others are saying.

Fields.MenuText: It's not all going to be fun and games. People are still going to die.
You'll also be providing aircraft and submarine protection to the support ships, remember.
Hopefully, there will be less tipping danger on the radio.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Kanchou. Believe me, I know. But this is the job I am the best suited for, and it will save lives.
I remember. It is good that my guns will not be idle, as vile as that feels to say.
Oh, be quiet, Kanchou - or I might toss you off during the next hard turn.
We're almost upon them. Are you ready?
I received radio confirmation before you, Kanchou. I was born ready.
@BATTLE
Yatta! Oh, Kanchou, that went perfectly! We were like a single entity, our force at a central point and our body always beyond their reach.
That's some poetry you have there, Nenohi. But you're right, you did an excellent job.
Dōmo arigatōgozaimashita! I will redecorate my entire bridge tonight to show my happiness with my new position.
Whatever you think is best, Nenohi. I'm happy you can keep the fleet safe, and yourself out of danger.
Now, I think, there will be fewer letters of condolences sent to families back home. I wish the Emperor could see this.
I'm sure if he saw how well this crew works together, he would be compelled to encourage his men to better work with those from other nations.
I can think of more than a few rulers who ought to take a look at what we can achieve out here.
I think people forget that we're all simply people, in the end. Sometimes all it takes is finding a bit of common ground.
Or a bit of common ocean! Still, out here with my sisters and brothers, I feel at home and safe.

Fields.MenuText: They're glad to have you as part of their family as well, Nenohi. The fleet always benefits from more caring souls.
You're an inspiration to me, Nenohi. I can't think of many people who would go as far as you just to make others feel comfortable and safe.
